senses.de: A conversation between two or more people, or a similar exchange between a person and a thing, or between two or more things
senses.ex: In the book, there is a witty dialogue between the two main characters.

Tips.title: Real Conversations
Tips.description: Used to describe realistic spoken exchanges that might occur in everyday life.
Tips.example: The dialogue in the cafe scene felt very natural.

Tips.title: Beyond Humans
Tips.description: May also refer to hypothetical exchanges with objects or concepts in creative writing.
Tips.example: The dialogue between the character and their conscience was intriguing.

Tips.title: Not Always Vocal
Tips.description: Can include internal or unspoken exchanges within a character's mind.
Tips.example: His internal dialogue revealed his true feelings.

senses.de: The lines spoken by characters in drama or fiction
senses.ex: Shakespeare's works are famous for their poetic dialogues.

Tips.title: Character Voices
Tips.description: Reflects the unique personality, background, and attitude of each character.
Tips.example: Her quick-witted dialogue made her the most memorable character.

Tips.title: Plot Advancement
Tips.description: Can reveal important plot details and character development.
Tips.example: The dialogue in the last chapter clarified the mystery.

senses.de: A formal discussion or negotiation between two or more parties
senses.ex: The government began a dialogue with the rebels for peace talks.

Tips.title: Purposeful Talk
Tips.description: Often aims to resolve conflicts, reach agreements, or understand different viewpoints.
Tips.example: The dialogue between the nations led to a historic treaty.

Tips.title: Structured Process
Tips.description: Involves careful planning and is often facilitated to ensure productive discussion.
Tips.example: The structured dialogue brought every party's concerns to light.

senses.de: A discussion in which two or more people or groups, especially religious groups, exchange their views
senses.ex: Interfaith dialogues are important to promote understanding among different religious groups.

Tips.title: Bridge Building
Tips.description: Seeks to enhance mutual understanding across cultural or religious divides.
Tips.example: Their dialogue helped bridge the gap between the communities.

Tips.title: Shared Values
Tips.description: Focuses on finding common ground despite differing beliefs or practices.
Tips.example: The interfaith dialogue highlighted shared values like compassion.

Chat.wordDefinition:
Chat refers to a casual conversation, often between friends or acquaintances.

It is usually done with the intention of exchanging information or ideas. In simpler terms, chat is used when two people are talking casually to each other, while dialogue is used when people are talking in a more serious or formal way, like in a meeting or classroom discussion.

Colloquy.wordDefinition:
Colloquy and dialogue are both words that refer to a conversation between two or more people.

However, colloquy typically refers to a more formal discussion, such as a debate or a political discussion, whereas dialogue can refer to any type of conversation, whether it's formal or informal.

For example, a group of politicians might have a colloquy about a new law, while two friends might have a casual dialogue about their weekend plans.

Communicate.wordDefinition:
Communicate means to convey or share information, thoughts or feelings with someone else.

Both communicate and dialogue are important in different situations. We use communicate when we want to express something to someone, whether it's through writing, speaking, or other means.

Conversation.wordDefinition:
The words conversation and dialogue are often used interchangeably, but there is a subtle difference.

A conversation is a general term that refers to any type of talk between two or more people.

It can be casual or formal, light-hearted or serious. A dialogue is a more structured conversation that involves two or more people exchanging ideas or opinions on a particular topic.

Both conversation and dialogue are important forms of communication, but they are applicable in different scenarios.

A conversation may occur in any setting, like a party, office, or family gathering when people are catching up or passing time.

Conversation is more informal while dialogues are more structured and goal-oriented.

Discourse.wordDefinition:
Discourse refers to a larger discussion or narrative that involves multiple perspectives or voices.

In other words, dialogue is a smaller-scale conversation while discourse is a broader discussion that may involve multiple conversations and viewpoints.

Dialogue can be useful for resolving conflicts or sharing information while discourse can help us understand complex issues from different perspectives.

Discussion.wordDefinition:
Dialogue and discussion both involve conversation or communication between two or more people.

Discussion refers to a conversation where the participants are more interested in expressing their own opinions or ideas than in listening to others.

Both dialogue and discussion have their place. Dialogue is most useful when trying to build relationships, resolve conflicts, or promote understanding between different groups or individuals.

Discussion can be useful when brainstorming ideas, debating issues, or making decisions.

Exchange.wordDefinition:
Exchange refers to the act of giving and receiving something between two or more parties.

Dialogue focuses on the exchange of thoughts and ideas between people, while exchange involves the transfer of tangible or intangible things between two or more parties.

Exchange is applicable in situations where there is an exchange of goods, services, or ideas between individuals or organizations.

Interchange.wordDefinition:
Dialogue and interchange both refer to a conversation or communication between two or more people.

However, dialogue typically implies a more formal, structured conversation, while interchange has a more informal and spontaneous connotation.

Dialogue can be used in professional or academic settings, such as a business meeting or a literary work, while interchange is often used in everyday conversations or discussions.

Parley.wordDefinition:
Parley refers to a discussion or conference between two sides that have different opinions, especially during a conflict or war.

In simpler terms, dialogue is a conversation to find common ground, while parley is a conversation to end a disagreement or conflict.

Talk.wordDefinition:
Talk refers to any form of communication that involves the exchange of information.

Talk can be used in any situation where people need to communicate, such as in everyday conversation, public speaking, or instructional settings.

Dialogue is a specific type of talk that involves respectful and open communication aimed at finding common ground, while talk refers to any form of communication.

quotes.Text: In music, what is very important is temporality of space and length, based on the breathing space the director gives the music within the film, by separating the music from various elements of reality, like noises, dialogues... That's how you treat music properly, but it doesn't always happen this way. Music is often blamed, but it's not its fault.
quotes.Title: Italian Composer
quotes.Name: Ennio Morricone

quotes.Text: For me dialogue is as essential in football as in life. I like to talk to my players and I never impose anything, I always give them the chance to make their own choices.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Coach
quotes.Name: Zico

quotes.Text: I would say I have sort of a natural gift for character, and following one person's point of view at a time, and dialogue, but I'm not naturally good at strong plot.
quotes.Title: Irish Playwright
quotes.Name: Emma Donoghue

quotes.Text: There is such a thing as my kind of actor, and how well they pull off my dialogue is a very, very important part of it.

quotes.Text: I think that if you're improvising on TV, it's a great way to help the dialogue between actors and writers.

quotes.Name: Zach Woods

quotes.Text: It's very important for me to have dialogues across racial lines.

quotes.Text: I'm interested in character and dialogue and exchange of ideas.

quotes.Name: Alexander McCall Smith

quotes.Text: Can't you see, we are in a dialogue with the universe?

quotes.Text: We had a dialogue coach. She helped us with our T's.
